subject: Art & Design
title: Color Blindness: Designing for All Eyes
description: A quick win: understand Color Blindness: Designing for All Eyes.

hook.text: Eight percent of men can't distinguish red from green. If your design relies on color alone, millions can't use it.

buildup.text: Color vision deficiency affects 300 million people worldwide. The most common type confuses red and green hues.

discovery.text: Accessible design uses redundant cues: icons, patterns, labels, and contrast â€” never color as the only differentiator.

twist.text: Traffic lights look identical to colorblind users. They navigate by position â€” top, middle, bottom â€” not by color.

climax.text: Facebook is blue because Mark Zuckerberg is red-green colorblind. Blue is the color he sees most vividly.

punchline.text: Good design doesn't just look right. It works for every eye.

quiz.question: Why should designers avoid using color as the only way to convey information?
options: Color vision deficiency affects millions, making color-only cues inaccessible
